questiontext.text:
Plastic is a material widely used in almost everything. In brief, the word means "pliable and easily {1:SHORTANSWER:=shaped}."
This material’s plasticity or plastic deformation makes it possible to be pressed, {1:SHORTANSWER:=moulded}, or extruded into solid objects of various {1:SHORTANSWER:=shapes}.

3D printers used two main technologies:
{1:SHORTANSWER:=Powder} bed fusion: the printers that use this technology compact masses of powder in layers.
Extrusion {1:SHORTANSWER:=deposition}: with this technology, the desire shape is created by adding the material in layers on a print bed.

<!-- Copyright © 2023 por Isabel Yago Lisbona --> <!-- Licencia Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0/deed.es --> Plastics are materials formed by chains of {1:SHORTANSWER:=carbon} and hydrogen atoms. We call these chains {1:SHORTANSWER:=polymers}, while the atoms that form them are called {1:SHORTANSWER:=monomers}.

<!-- Copyright © 2023 por Isabel Yago Lisbona --> <!-- Licencia Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0/deed.es --> Thermoplastic materials are plastics that are {1:SHORTANSWER:=softened} by heating, and can be formed and {1:SHORTANSWER:=melted} as many times as we like.

<!-- Copyright © 2023 por Isabel Yago Lisbona --> <!-- Licencia Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0/deed.es --> Elastomers are very {1:SHORTANSWER:=flexible} materials that recover their shape and {1:SHORTANSWER:=dimensions} when external forces stop acting on them.

<!-- Copyright © 2023 por Isabel Yago Lisbona --> <!-- Licencia Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0/deed.es --> Elastomers degrade easily with the {1:SHORTANSWER:=heat} and cannot be re-melted once they have been {1:SHORTANSWER:=formed}.

<!-- Copyright © 2023 por Isabel Yago Lisbona --> <!-- Licencia Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0/deed.es --> Thermoset plastics can be {1:SHORTANSWER:=shaped} using heat; however, once they have been formed, they cannot be re-melted to {1:SHORTANSWER:=create} different forms.

<!-- Copyright © 2023 por Isabel Yago Lisbona --> <!-- Licencia Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0/deed.es --> {1:SHORTANSWER:=Extrusion}: this procedure is used with thermoplastics to obtain long products, {1:SHORTANSWER:=pipes}, profiles, etc.

Plastics are extremely useful but they generate large quantities of {1:SHORTANSWER:=waste} that build up on the surface of the Earth.
Unlike other materials (such as wood), plastics are mainly {1:SHORTANSWER:=non-biodegradable}; this means that they do not degrade over time.

<!-- Copyright © 2023 por Isabel Yago Lisbona --> <!-- Licencia Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0/deed.es --> Thermoplastics are washed, ground up and fed into an {1:SHORTANSWER:=extruder}, which uses heat to {1:SHORTANSWER:=melt} them in order to make new parts. We call this process mechanical {1:SHORTANSWER:=recycling}.

Plastics used in 3D printing, PLA or ABS:
{1:SHORTANSWER:=PLA}: this plastic is created from natural materials such as corn, starch and sugar cane.
{1:SHORTANSWER:=ABS}: a very tough, hard and rigid plastic. It can withstand high temperatures and is easy to paint.
{1:SHORTANSWER:=ABS}: it has a very high melting point and must be heated to 230-260ºC for use in additive manufacturing.
{1:SHORTANSWER:=PLA}: it is biodegradable and does not release toxic gases when it is used in printing. This material is also much more difficult to machine and paint than {1:SHORTANSWER:=ABS}.

A 3D printer is a machine that can print figures with {1:SHORTANSWER:=volume} from a computer design.
Because {1:SHORTANSWER:=thermoplastic} materials are easy to mould and form they are used in 3D printing, also called additive manufacturing.
